Award.AwardTitle: Fostering and Diversifying Student Participation in the International Parallel and Distributed Processing Symposium

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to broaden and diversifying the participation of students at The International Parallel and Distributed Processing Symposium (IPDPS 2017) and its PhD Forum. IPDPS is a premier international conference for presenting the research results, problem solutions, and insights on new challenges in parallel and distributed computing. It is the flagship conference of the IEEE Computer Society's Technical Committee on Parallel Processing. Its PhD Forum is a well established program that has evolved over the past ten years. Its innovative model provides a comprehensive experience for students, including research, career development, and networking. The forum is structured as a series of panels for career advice, relaxed mentoring sessions over lunch, speed networking, and a formal research poster session. Through the multiple sessions students are instructed on best practices for research and presentation, while getting a first hand experience on authoring, structuring, and presenting a research poster. At the same time, students are provided with valuable advice and perspectives from leaders on the field regarding career choices. As stated by NSF's mission, this project indirectly promotes the progress of science and contributes toward a more productive workforce development by investing in the future generation of researchers in the parallel and distributed processing field.

Ultimately, the IPDPS student program provides effective opportunities for training and mentoring, student networking, and integration of students into the research community. Since the goal of this project is to promote a broader and more diverse participation of students, a targeted and conscious effort will be made to reach out to students that typically would not be able to attend the conference without financial support, including undergraduate students, graduate students in their first year, students attending their first conference, and students that belong to underrepresented groups in STEM fields, particularly women.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The funding supported students participating in the 31st IEEE International Parallel & Distributed Processing Symposium (IPDPS’17) held in Orlando FL., on May 29 to June 2, 2017. The IPDPS Conference provided student travel grants to encourage participation by students where they can explore opportunities for technical growth and broader engagement with the community at large.

Awards were in the form of reimbursement post conference participation. The PIs decided to support all student applicants (albeit at a lower level) who applied by the deadline resulting in 50 students supported through NSF funds. 18 of the funded students were self-identified as female or underrepresented minority.  There were other awards for international student participants as well, those awards were funded from IEEE-TCPP funds.

26 of the 50 funded students participated in the PhD Forum. The PhD Forum is a space where participants can present their research to the whole IPDPS community and get mentoring from established researchers. This year the PhD forum included a poster session, a workshop on presentation skills, a panel on career planning, and a panel on best papers.

Jiroslaw Zola (State University of New York at Buffalo), Umit Catalyurek (Ohio State University), Jay Lofstead (SNL) and Trilce Estrada (University of New Mexico) were involved in getting the applications, screening them and making awards. UNM staff helped with the disbursement of awards.

Addendum # 1

In terms of fulfilling the objective of enhancing the participation of traditionally underrepresented minority groups in the parallel and distributed processing field, this project reached out to these communities through (1) active promotion of the program at the SC 2016 Women in HPC workshop, (2) advertisement in Grace Hopper scholarship social media channels, and (3) advertisement in The Pipeline Workshop: Diversifying the HPC Workforce held at UNM in January of 2017. As a result of this effort, the number of US-based female students funded grew from 5 in 2016 to 15 in 2016, additionally, 3 of the funded male students self-identified as being part of a minority group.
